Troy Farmers’ Market Application

The goal of the Troy Farmers Market/ Arts & Crafts is to offer the City a vehicle in which they can strengthen and build the local economy, while offering its citizens a way to gain ownership in government projects and receive the sense of goodwill that the community and the City of Troy would like to extend through it's rich, rural and agricultural resources. WE offer these guidelines to help preserve the resources and facilities of the City as good stewards but make it available for the use of the community that it belongs to. As ambassadors of good will on behalf of the City of Troy, we offer regulations that will guide and protect staff and participants so that they can serve and protect our community. This is a project that can facilitate building relationships with citizens and small businesses, and seek to problem solve when issues interfere with City revitalization, and to continue to magnify the community resources.

Months, Days and Hours of Operation

The Troy Farmers Market/ Arts & Crafts will be held the first Saturday of each month, with few exceptions due to scheduling conflicts or holidays. This event was designed to promote goodwill, to support local farmers or growers and encourage cohesiveness in the community is regulated by the Council and market managers, and Farmers Market Board members. No other event may operate during this day that will create confusion concerning who the event sponsors are, or their purpose. No event such as a flea market, market, area sale, farmers market, or farmers stand may operate on a scheduled Troy Farmers Market/ Arts & Crafts day, or a scheduled City sponsored event without permission from the City within the City of Troy or in the limits of its jurisdiction.

Hours of operation shall be from 8 a.m. until 12 p.m., with set up time one hour prior to the designated start time for purposes of set-up, and shall occupy the site no longer than one hour after the designated closing time for clean-up. Days and hours of operation are subject to change at the discretion of the Troy Farmers Market Managers, and the Troy Farmers Market Board with the City of Troy‘s City Council‘s approval. The hours of operation strictly prohibit forestalling by vendors or their agents.

The market will be located at the Troy Pavilion on 201 East Main Street Downtown Troy or within the City of Troy Community Center. The vendor spots and the electrical usage at the City pavilion during market hours are free of charge. The City of Troy reserves the right to charge a fee in the future if they desire. Notice will be given to the vendors ahead of time Usage charges for electricity will be charged to the vendors who utilize the electricity only. These electrical fees will be paid on demand. No vendor may return to sell at future markets until their fees are paid in full and in good faith. Vendors will be permitted to take turns backing up their vehicles in order to unload goods prior to the sale then park in an approved parking area the entire duration of the market. Parking in the handicapped parking spaces are prohibited unless you are eligible to use handicapped parking. Once the market hour has begun, no moving vehicles are allowed near the market area as a safety precaution. No vehicles may block the driveways to the fire station or the police station or obstruct traffic in any way on city streets.
  • A reseller is only eligible to participate at the Troy Farmers Market/ Arts & Crafts under certain conditions with permission from the market managers. Reselling may occur by local farmers or local growers who are subsidizing their items not yet in season or not available by our local growers. Resold items may not exceed 40% of growers market able items and must be documented to be bought within 100 miles of the area by the original grower through receipts. All growers are subject to inspection by market managers. The items must be approved at least 72 hours before sales so that the market managers can determine if the reselling will interfere with local growers’ marketing first. The goal of the market is to promote local farmers and growers but also offer a variety of products to the community.
  • No canned whole tomatoes, tomato products, salsas, or sauces, custard pies or items cooked with eggs are permitted to be sold in the City of Troy without appropriate licensing or permits from the Bell County Health Department. Foods also forbidden for sale in the City but are not limited to burritos, calzones, burgers, hot dogs, or any foods sold that are not being marketed by a licensed food handler that may pose a possible risk to the community’s health.
  • Each vendor shall obtain an application in the form and content specified by the Farmers Market Managers or the Troy Market Board as well as a copy of the rules and regulations used to govern the market. Applications will contain pertinent information such as: name of vendor, physical address, telephone number, and a product list of items to be sold. A duly authorized agent shall present a written, signed, letter stating the authorization to represent the Vendor. An application must be submitted 48 hours before the upcoming market date.
  • Vendors who apply for the spaces and do not attend the “Troy Farmers Market” or no longer wish to utilize the space are required to contact the Market managers within 60 days. This will provide the opportunity for other qualified vendors to participate. In the case, that all available spaces are occupied, a waiting list will be compiled.
  • Market Manager- An agent or agents who has gained permission from the Mayor and City Council to oversee the development and the operation of the Troy Farmers Market/ Arts & Crafts on behalf of the City of Troy, Texas. Managers may use the name Troy Farmers Market/ Arts & Crafts or even Troy Farmers Market to promote, advertise or exercise goodwill on behalf of the City of Troy and the vendors of the market. Responsibilities may also include but may not be limited to receiving and reviewing applications from prospective vendors and fostering good relationships with them. Maintain records of the vendors and inspect them when it becomes necessary. Remind them to seek proper licensing and encourage them to follow the guidelines of the various levels of government. Offer non-professional advice for marketing their products and do some social networking on their behalf via the Troy Farmers Market website or through social networking. Recruit vendors to improve the quality and the diversity of the market so that it may appeal to a wide variety of customers in the community. Make decisions concerning the operations of the market based on research and experience which may help enhance the local economy, safeguard public safety and create an atmosphere for community cohesiveness. Help inform the community of the importance of fresh produce and buying locally. Look for ways to offer the public any health or community resources. Allow charities or fundraisers to join the market for sales. Managers will problem solve and/or keep the Council abreast of problems or important decisions concerning the market or community. Communicate regularly with the Police and Fire Department staff. The managers will appoint members for the Farmers Market Board. The managers will also be able to report to the Council.

The City of Troy provides access to bathrooms, and a pavilion with a hard surface that allows a 10 X 10 marketing space, along with plenty of green space on which people can market. There may be times when a vendor will have to provide their own shade using a canopy if they are required to set up out from under the pavilion. All vendors are responsible for providing their own tables, chairs or displays. Sale items, canopies, and umbrellas, must be placed in a manner that will not obstruct sidewalks, allowing pedestrians ample room to move freely. The Market Managers have the authority to determine if locations are appropriate.

Signs may be used on the pavilion or in areas in a a way that will not damage the City’s property, block walkways, or appear to cause a potential hazard for other vendors or marketers. Signs can not obscure the views of other vendors or marketers or be too distracting. Market Managers will monitor signs and their usage.

  • Vendor spaces shall be on a first come, first served basis. If a business or vendor has special requirements for their business the Market managers may designate assigned permanent spaces on their behalf. Please contact the managers of issues at least 48 hours before the sale.
  • Vendors are responsible for providing their own tables, chairs, or displays. Signs may be used on the pavilion in a way that will not damage the City’s property, block walkways or appear to cause a potential hazard for other vendors or marketers. Signs can not obscure the views of other vendors or marketers or be too distracting. Market managers will monitor sign uses.
  • The City of Troy provides access to restrooms, along with a hard surface and pavilion for the Market. There may be a time when a vendor will have to provide their own canopy to set up with out from under the pavilion. The Market managers have the authority to determine if locations are appropriate.
Each vendor is responsible for collecting his/ her own sales taxes, where it is applicable.

Holding the City of Troy Harmless

The City of Troy shall be held harmless for any accidents, injuries, or other occurrences in relation to the “Troy Farmers Market/ Arts and Crafts.” Vendors or their agents shall be held responsible for any damage to City or County.

Vendors should make every attempt to resolve minor disputes between themselves; especially if it clearly does not involve violation of this Ordinance; which is designed to set-forth rules, regulations and guidelines pertaining to the safety and welfare of the City of Troy and its inhabitants.

Violation of any provision of the Troy Farmers Market rules shall be a material breach and default by the vendor. The vendor will be asked to vacate the premises immediately. Failure to vacate may subject the seller to civil and/or criminal remedies. We reserve the right to prohibit any seller’s participation at any time if and when the seller shall be found to be in violation of any market rule, health and sanitation practices, or eligibility requirements or do not have the appropriate permits, if needed. Neither the City of Troy, the Market managers, nor the Troy Farmers market board will be held liable for non-compliances with federal, state, or local laws.

The Farmers Market board shall reserve the right to revise the Farmers Market rules and operations at any time it deems appropriate and shall post notice of such revisions for vendors which may include fees or contracts.

Guidelines for Market Management has been revised and made public on this day January 7, 2012.

The City of Troy City Council members reserve the right to further revise this instrument to better serve all of the citizens of Troy. The Troy Farmers Market/ Arts & Crafts is a Troy citizen, volunteer run project of the City of Troy.
